text: uh hi everyone scruffany bufftano here
the internet's busiest music nerd and
it's time for a review of the new
tropical fuckstorm album deep states yep
it's a brand new lp from australian art
punk and noise rock outfit tropical
fuckstorm i've been covering their work
ever since gareth littyard he had fiona
kitzchin separated off from the
legendary drones to start this band with
erica dunn and lauren hamill and it's
been a wild chaotic and apocalyptic ride
so far few bands of the modern era have
captured that tangled ugly end times
energy in the way that tropical
fuckstorm has
and now that [ __ ] is worse than ever
that would make i think this band's uh
sound more relevant than it's ever been
but strangely enough tropical
fuckstorm's music this time around on
deep states didn't really have the
instant impact for me that it's had thus
far maybe it's me but since this record
dropped in august i've just found it to
be
kind of a tough nut to crack even if a
few of the tracks here sounded like they
could have easily been featured on the
band's previous records so yes i've been
sitting with deep states for a while
figuring out if i like it or i dislike
it for one i think deep states has the
weakest production of all of tropical
fuckstorm's records so far though it
does seem like there's a lot of intent
and purpose behind the way this album
sounds though the way the group chooses
certain instruments in the mix to be
compressed to the point where they are
distorted crackly which kind of works in
the case of the more wiry and cathartic
tracks on the record like the opener or
the lyrically ingenious gaff or give a
[ __ ] fatigue a track about being beaten
down by the overload of negative and
disastrous information as a result of
the internet news media social media the
harsh and burnt out aesthetics of this
record somehow enhances the closing
track as well which is essentially just
this synth instrumental these desolate
passages of harmonies that sound a
little bit like something mike dean
might do for a kanye record overall i
think it's a perfect finish to a project
that is uh this grim but by that same
token there are just as many tracks on
this thing that these production choices
handily ruin the vocal layers on
bluebeam baby being as distorted as they
are just makes them obnoxiously grating
all the compression and the distortion
suffocates the grim crescendo at the
finish of suburbiopia which kind of
needed to go off without a hitch given
just how tedious the first leg of that
song is this mixed bag of production and
songwriting continues into the second
half of the lp2 bummer sanger for
example is an apt number about the
restless and panicked feelings of the
pandemic and the lockdowns gareth sings
out frantically on this track about
feeling like he can't relax like he's
stuck inside meanwhile this is
contrasted with these blaring passages
of vocal harmonies and wailing leads
that feel like the sense of crushing
dread meanwhile i'm kind of perplexed by
the song the donkey this one doesn't
feel so much like a proper song as much
as it comes off like a live
to tape experiment gone wrong especially
with those falsetto vocals and i get
that looseness and cacophony is sort of
the name of the game for tropical
fuckstorm but there just doesn't seem to
be a strong song or groove or riff for
all of this chaos to sort of orbit
around here though the whole thing does
come to a very cathartic finish the
instrumental on reporting of a failed
campaign fell a little flat for me as
well but i do have to admit this is one
of the band's most lyrically clever
songs ever it's a story song with
several different corrupt characters
that have different backgrounds and
trajectories eventually meeting at some
point at a very bloody end and i'm not
going to spoil the whole thing but if
you pay attention to the narrative here
you're gonna hang on every word then
legal ghost is easily one of the band's
most haunting songs ever and that's not
just because uh you know ghost is in the
title but there is something genuinely
powerful about the refrains on this
track with gareth exploring these
feelings of loneliness and loss through
the idea of being turned into a ghost
something
unlovable unknowable untouchable to
where even if you are with someone
you're still in a sense alone the
tragedy and lyrics and the gloominess of
this track there's almost a classic bad
seeds vibe to it in a way as well the
screaming and yelping guitars that bury
the track at the very end do come off a
bit strong though but at this point at
the very end of the record that's just
one of many weird production choices and
blemishes that i'm just not really all
that into the production on this one is
just more grating purposefully so this
time around and in my opinion it's not
necessarily for the better so overall i
found deep states to be kind of a mixed
bag but in my opinion even a so-so
tropical [ __ ] storm record is better
than a lot of stuff that's out there
right now not to mention that even in
2021 the band unflinchingly stares into
the void of despair and manages to pull
inspiration out i'm feeling a strong six
to a light seven on this one tran
position have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
what would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should i review
next hit the like if you like please
subscribe and please don't cry hit the
bell as well over here next to my head
it's another video you can check out hit
that up or the link to subscribe to the
channel anthony fantano tropical
fuckstorm
forever
